This is Lydia Hernandez’s blog that dives into all this Husker Volleyball. Her most recent being who she thinks the next Libero will be after Lexi Rodriquez graduates.
Lydia Hernandez is a junior at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln studying Sports Media & Communication, ADPR, and Broadcasting. She is from Omaha and has always loved being creative. Early on she joined social media and knew she wanted to work in the creative world—whether through social media, photography, videography, or writing. Currently Hernandez holds multiple jobs, Most notably with the Nebraska Athletics Creative team, as a COJMC Ambassador, and is an owner of her own photography business.

title: Do statistics determine who the next Nebraska libero will be?
text:
With every great college libero, there’s always an end. When Kenzie Maloney graduated, it felt like a hole was left in the program for Husker nation. Lexi Rodriguez stepped in and quickly became a fan favorite in the Star City. Now, as the libero from Sterling, Illinois, prepares to graduate from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln this season, the question on every volleyball fan’s mind is: who will be next?
Being a libero requires both mental and physical qualities, but the real question here is: can statistics help us determine who is the strongest candidate for the next libero?
As far as playing time goes, the two players vying for the spot are Sophomore Defensive Specialist, Laney Choboy and True Freshman Defensive Specialist, Olivia Mauch.
Serving is one of the few aspects a player can control in volleyball. It requires a deep focus on where you want the ball to go and strength to determine the pace and accuracy. For a libero, serving ability is a strong indicator of skill. Since they  only serve  once every six rotations, this is one of the most direct comparisons we can make between the two players and Lexi Rodriguez.
Our data shows that Mauch’s and Choboy’s Aces Per Set (APS) are not as high as Rodriguez’s, but they’re not far off either. This leaves room for improvement, giving both of them something to work on in the upcoming season. But don’t misunderstand—both players are strong servers in their own right.
Serve receive is often regarded as one of the most important skills for a libero. The job demands covering the back row, positioning yourself to ensure the ball reaches the setter with accuracy. Based on our data, Mauch has a slightly higher serve receive percentage than Choboy (by 2.3%) and is just under Rodriguez’s by (1.2%). In Husker volleyball, the back row is always solid, but these slight differences in percentages do stand out.
The other key stats to consider are digs per set and assists per set. Being able to dig some of the hardest attacks in the world and get those out of system balls when the setter is playing defense is super important.Again, Choboy and Mauch are neck and neck, so what does this mean for the final decision? As I mentioned earlier, this is Husker Volleyball—they recruit the best players in the country. Ultimately, the choice of who becomes the next libero for Nebraska involves more than just statistics. However, stats do provide some important insights. Mauch has a slightly stronger serve receive, closely mirroring Rodriguez, while Choboy has a more powerful and accurate serve.
Ultimately, this will be a tough decision for Head Coach John Cook. Beyond the stats, he will need to review extensive game and practice footage, evaluating how each player interacts with their teammates, their quickness on their feet, and most importantly, their leadership abilities both on and off the court. Do they understand their teammates’ strengths and weaknesses? Can they call out plays and communicate effectively with hitters? Are they loud and assertive, getting as many touches as possible with no hesitation? These are all crucial factors that Coach Cook will need to consider when selecting Nebraska’s next libero.
